title: ecdsa123
author: ecdsa123
created_time: January 02, 2023, 08:24:42 PMLast edit: August 31, 2024, 02:53:32 PM by ecdsa123

comments.author: _Counselor
comments.body: I don't clearly understand what needs to be tested. If the question is "does the given public key lies in given range" than the answer is no, it doesn't.

comments.author: Kpot87
comments.body: Quote from: _Counselor on January 03, 2023, 05:51:28 AMI don't clearly understand what needs to be tested. If the question is "does the given public key lies in given range" than the answer is no, it doesn't.how you know this ?

comments.author: bnbstorm
comments.body: Quote from: Kpot87 on January 21, 2023, 08:27:50 PMQuote from: _Counselor on January 03, 2023, 05:51:28 AMI don't clearly understand what needs to be tested. If the question is "does the given public key lies in given range" than the answer is no, it doesn't.how you know this ?Provided range is not quite big. They can run every possible pattern and match it with provided key and tell if it is in that range or not. This range scanning time is based on hardware you have.For more information every bitcoin address is generated from a specific range of private keys. Nearly every 256-bit number is a valid ECDSA private key. Specifically, any 256-bit number from 0x1 to 0xFFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFE BAAE DCE6 AF48 A03B BFD2 5E8C D036 4140 is a valid private key.

comments.author: Kpot87

Specifically, any 256-bit number from 0x1 to 0xFFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFF FFFE BAAE DCE6 AF48 A03B BFD2 5E8C D036 4140 is a valid private key.its clear. i mean that _Counselor scan range and give answer.
